lom:description.lom:string: "The nationwide decline in the percentage of women obtaining bachelors degrees in computer science has been noted in Klawe and Levenson (1995) [8]. This phenomenon can be observed in the Computer Science ((XC) Department at the California Polytechnic State IJniversity (Cal Poly), San Luis Obispo. as well. As of Winter quarter, 1995, there were 642 students enrolled in the Computer Science and the Computer Engineering majors. Of these students, 540 were male and 102 were female, thus undergraduate women constitute a mere 16?Z0 of the major. This percentage of women in the major has decreased by 7?ZOfrom Fall of 1988. Recently, many studies have been carried out in an attempt to explain the decline of womens participation in the fields of computer science and computer engineering. Reasons that have been cited include social differences in the way boys and girls are raised, stereotypes and fake images of computing, different learning styles and needs of women, and lack of role models for women in computing. In this paper, we focus our attention on the factors within the control of the departments, such as how the curricula can be enhanced to address the learning needs of female students in particular, and aH students in general."

lom:keyword.lom:string: studies, girl, gender differences, female, survey, computer programming, career opportunities, retaining, women

lom:title.lom:string: On the retention of female computer science students
